dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, hey, have you been following these, uh, US-China trade talks? Seems like they're, like, heading for a breakthrough, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, hey, have you been following these, uh, U S-China trade talks? Seems like they're, like, heading for a breakthrough, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These latest developments cast fresh doubt on prospects for a successful conclusion to the US-China trade negotiations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. Kinda surprising, to be honest. After all that back and forth, you'd think it'd be, like, super contentious. What's the secret sauce?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. Kinda surprising, to be honest. After all that back and forth, you'd think it'd be, like, super contentious. What's the secret sauce?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's interesting. This article I read suggests it's not about the *substance* of the deal at all. It's actually about, um, negotiating styles and norms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's interesting. This article I read suggests it's not about the substance of the deal at all. It's actually about, um, negotiating styles and norms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I suspect a clash of negotiating norms and styles may have played a role, in addition to differences on substance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Like, how they talk to each other? Not what they're talking about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Like, how they talk to each other? Not what they're talking about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The author, who teaches this EMBA course at Columbia, he does these mock negotiations, right? And he says that, uh, the differences in norms, once both sides are aware of them, can actually lead to a *swift* resolution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The author, who teaches this E M B A course at Columbia, he does these mock negotiations, right? And he says that, uh, the differences in norms, once both sides are aware of them, can actually lead to a swift resolution.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Discussing how to negotiate before the talks start would reduce the chances of such a clash, and therefore save a great deal of disappointment and frustration further down the road.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, what are these different styles then? Like, what's the American way versus, say, the Chinese way?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, what are these different styles then? Like, what's the American way versus, say, the Chinese way?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, Americans, generally, we tend to take a holistic approach. We want to agree on, like, all nine topics simultaneously, if there are nine topics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, Americans, generally, we tend to take a holistic approach. We want to agree on, like, all nine topics simultaneously, if there are nine topics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most American negotiators adopt a checklist approach... The Chinese, by contrast, are accustomed to taking a more holistic approach...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, you want the whole package deal, up front.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, you want the whole package deal, up front.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. But the Chinese, they're more of a "checklist" approach. And they have this norm: "everything is agreed until something is agreed."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. But the Chinese, they're more of a checklist approach. And they have this norm: everything is agreed until something is agreed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese, by contrast, are accustomed to taking a more holistic approach, and follow a norm of nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, "everything is agreed until something is agreed"? What does that even mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, everything is agreed until something is agreed? What does that even mean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's fascinating. Imagine nine topics. You talk for two days, hit an impasse on the first six. Then, on day three, you agree on the last three.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's fascinating. Imagine nine topics. You talk for two days, hit an impasse on the first six. Then, on day three, you agree on the last three.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Let us say that the two sides have reached an agreement on the first six topics after two days of talks. On the final day, they reach an impasse on the last three points...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: From the US perspective, you'd think the first six are still stuck. But the Chinese side might then say, "Great! We fully endorse the initial agreement on the first six topics!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: From the U S perspective, you'd think the first six are still stuck. But the Chinese side might then say, Great! We fully endorse the initial agreement on the first six topics!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and the Chinese side declares suddenly, from the US teams viewpoint that they have to alter the agreement on the first six topics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. So the US team thinks they're totally trustworthy and sincere, like it was a huge success. But, uh, the article says they might both be intending to be "devious."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. So the U S team thinks they're totally trustworthy and sincere, like it was a huge success. But, uh, the article says they might both be intending to be devious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At this point, the American team may very well feel that the Chinese side is untrustworthy or insincere... In my class, we discuss how talks may sometimes collapse purely due to differences in negotiating styles, without either party intending to be devious.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not devious in a bad way, necessarily. It's just that for the Chinese, when they disagreed on the first six, they had no expectations about the last three. Once those last three fell into place, the tradeoffs among *all nine* topics were unchanged for them. So, the first six are good to go!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not devious in a bad way, necessarily. It's just that for the Chinese, when they disagreed on the first six, they had no expectations about the last three. Once those last three fell into place, the tradeoffs among all nine topics were unchanged for them. So, the first six are good to go!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the discussion about these three topics turned out to be quite different from what they had expected, they asked to revisit the first six, because the various tradeoffs among the nine topics had changed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, they just expect things to evolve? And for earlier agreements to not be set in stone until everything is done?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, they just expect things to evolve? And for earlier agreements to not be set in stone until everything is done?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each would have expected the agreement on these six points to be only temporary, and subject to revision based on the outcome of the discussions about the last three topics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. For them, it would be weird if you *didn't* affirm the first six points after the last three were settled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. For them, it would be weird if you didn't affirm the first six points after the last three were settled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the above impasse had occurred between two opposing Chinese negotiating teams, neither side would have found it strange had the other asked to revisit the first six topics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, if you're a negotiator, what do you even *do* with this? Do you, like, try to hash out the negotiation style *before* you even start negotiating?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, if you're a negotiator, what do you even do with this? Do you, like, try to hash out the negotiation style before you even start negotiating?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, no, actually. The article says you shouldn't try to agree on norms. You just assume your own is universally shared. But the key is that *harmonization of expectations* happens if both sides are *aware* of these different styles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, no, actually. The article says you shouldn't try to agree on norms. You just assume your own is universally shared. But the key is that harmonization of expectations happens if both sides are aware of these different styles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In my class, I suggest to the students that before their two teams sit down to negotiate, they should first discuss and try to agree on the norms that will govern the talks and not simply assume that their own norm is universally shared.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, just understand the other side's weirdness? [chuckles]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, just understand the other side's weirdness?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And surprisingly, this "everything-is-agreed-until-something-is-agreed" approach can actually be favorable to the American side if *they* understand it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And surprisingly, this everything-is-agreed-until-something-is-agreed approach can actually be favorable to the American side if they understand it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, the nothing-is-agreed-until-everything-is-agreed approach is not inherently unfavorable to the American side.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So it's not about the details of the trade deal at all then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not about the details of the trade deal at all then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article actually posits that negotiations between countries are "very easy in terms of substance." It's the style that can unnecessarily impede talks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article actually posits that negotiations between countries are very easy in terms of substance. It's the style that can unnecessarily impede talks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the US-China trade talks have shown, negotiations between countries are hard enough in terms of substance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, cultural awareness is key, even when you're not *trying* to be culturally aware? Just knowing it's there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, cultural awareness is key, even when you're not trying to be culturally aware? Just knowing it's there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Precisely. It's all about navigating those unspoken rules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It's all about navigating those unspoken rules.
